Portcr's old friend, Com. La Bordc lost no Tina
in accepting the invitation, by commencing 10
put in state of preparation his dsposable force
consisting of the Loyahy; q frigate ofthe largest
class, and the Arathusa frigate, and Hercules

With these vessels he got under weigh, and pa,
sed MS this moment. II is doubtful if he has
not gone to windward first, to fall in with Ii.
Casilda Frgate, and two briggs that went out
some days ago, to cruise tor some Patriot prwa,
teers of Mantanzas., think it not unlikely, as

lures ever put on board ship. He has to con.
tend Vreport says true. and have no doubt Of

ing good officers, and a crew OF English and
.4nericnn sealncn. 1t is said that Porter has one

board his o,cn ship, brought out to man pm.
yes: Taking into view the numerical force Of

if the squadrons come in sight, haJthe Spanisf

The piedm0NtcSc Gazette relates the toll
lowing discovery recently made in cXcavat-
ing the ruins of Pompeii.


"TURlN, Nov. 23.


1--WE receive from Naples notice Of dis
covcry lately made in Pompei, which will
be highly agreeable to all our readers who
regard the memory of the Romans; this dis
coverp is absolutely new. In the recent cX-
cavatinns of a house near Treiionica, there
were found five glass Jars perfectly closed,
and placed in small wooden box these jars
being conveyed to the Royal Museum, were
carefully cleared of the earth which Coverl,i
the outside, and it was found that two of
them contained a thick and liquid substance
in good preservation, which, Oh accurate ex-
animation, proved to be conserat of olives,
prepared for the table Of some Pompcian
! Gastronome, eighteen centuries ago: they
are still entire which would appear marvel
4 lous If not fabulous, were it not confirmed
! by an authentic report. In another jar there
was a thick buteraceous sauce made OF the
roe of fish. His Majesty the King of the
Two Sicilies, being Immediately informed
of this unparalleled discovery desired to see 1t
and ordered an accurate analysis to be made
Of it.


"Perhaps the sauce here spoken OF is th'
famous Garum, the delight OF the ilastnou
Gourmans, os ancient Rome; it is know
that this suuce was made of the roe of fish
and therefore had much resemblance will
the substance found.


"TURION, Nov IS.
t "The following is the account given Of tn
, examination of the substance found i'll one
the jars at Pompcii. We think it useless t
report the examination of the olives, farthe
a ROMAN SAUCE.

"rhs substance is much softer than the
olives; it is of greenish-yellow colour. it
has strong rancid smell, and in the mass
are small globues resembling the roe of fish,

well determine. This substance is on the

terminate substance, in some degree analo-
gous to the sweet principle of fixed oils. 1t
should seem that originally it was no other

rather than annual, since the distillation of

"A visit tc the port of Toulou has engross-
ed much time and attention. After Brest it
is the largest naval depot in France, and is
indeed ast and magnificent establishment.
Nature tas already done much in forming
one of the finest harbors in the Mediterrane-
an, and the ambition of Louis 14th and of
Napoleon has not failed to add every thing
that art could DO TO render those natural adj
vautages as eIfcctual as possible. Almost
every thing necessary in the equipment of
ships OF war, and which is required for the
expenditure of the Arsenal is manufactured
in the establishment itself, such as canvass,
cordage, iron work and the like. These
manufactures and the other work OF the
yard OF course require an immense deal OF
labour, which is performed by about four
hundred galley slaves or convicts, under the
superintendent of large number keep
4 ers. In France, the system OF criminal u-
! risprudence is very mild and rarely involves
the punishment of death; but for great oifenc


es, the criminals are sentenced to hard labor
for life. or for shorter periods, according to
the degree of their criminality. In order to
employ the large number of criminals which
the numerous and dense population ofthis
country naturally affords, they send then to
their different naval arsenals where they are
fed on a healthy vegetable diet, and are kept
constantly well employ ed. Escape is scarce
. ly possible and is almost inevitably followed
by the criminals being brought back to full
fiji an augmented sentence. At Tculon,
there are five three deckers, ten ships of the
lne, and as many frgates, with some small
er vessels. Two ships ct $50 guns built in
1912, bv Napoleon, and called then the
"Austerlitz" and "Marengo," are now SC
completely rotten, as to have been condemn
ed; they were constructed OF green TIMBER
Napoleon thinking to create a navy by the
mere force Of his will. A reply of the ship.
keeper of the no7v "Royal Louis" to my
, question respecting the cruises his worn-o Out


ship had made, will give good idea of the
preponderence of the British Navy, and o


the little efficiency and enterprise of thu
: French. She has made campaigns, Sir, ha


been at eight leagues distance from Toulon
a and even fred several conps-de canon.


:, Oh that we had on our coast such har
? botr and arsenal as Toulon. There bein!


no tide in the Me literrancan, the sea alway


remains at the same level for it Is bas
i. without a river, and is accessible with mos
y winds for any draft. 1t is such a place a


one having most, most needs.

AWFUL FIRE AT ALEXANDRIA,. A.


A few minutes before nine O'Clock yester-
day morning, an alarming Fire broke out III
the town of Alexandria. 1t was soon per
ceived from this city; and, colG as the
weather was, (thcrmometer at lo') our
townsmen turned out With alacrity and al
most literally flew to the assistance OF 'nei,
neighbours. The Engine from the Capitoi
Hill, with its hose was under way IN rev
minutes after the fire was dlscovered.--A
bout three hundred persons from the Navy
Yard, headed by Captain Booth, were uh-
der way almost as soon, but having lurtner
to 60 did not arrive quite as early on .ie
ground. The Engine from the Post Ol1lcc
Department, with its fine hose got under
way as soon as the fire was ascertalhea 10
be serious, and had just started when an eX-
nress arrived to our Mayor from the Mayor
of Alexandria, soliciting aid, upon which
the Engine of e Second ward, and that
from the First were notified, and were un~
der way. Nor were our Georgetown neigh
bors behind hand: with great SPIRIT they
went down in numbers IN carriages, on
horseback, and on foot, carrying also, 1t IS
believed, their engine. All the Marines on
the station, were also carried down oy Gap
tain IIowle, under the orders OF Col. lien
derson and carrying an engine with them;
and though they did not arrive until the iife
was got under, afforded important service
as guards. The whole number OF persons
who went down from this SIDE OF the river
could not be less than thousand. II we APP
pear to dwell too much upon this pubic spl-
rited conduct of our citizens on TINS occasion,
let it be recollected that the distance to
I 4 4 q. . H.. r. -
I from was seven miles, and that the engines
and men arrived there about the time the


fire WAS most appalling. II any other cause
j for eAultation is thought necessary TO Justi-


fy it. let it be found in the fact, that the fire
was arre stet, and a vast amount oi property


rescued from the Jaws Of destruction, by the


aid thus afforded. The first suocour from the


city arrived about eleven o'clock, and wa


followed by successive supplies. Our friend


at Aiexahdra, exhausted by fatigue ant


anxiety, were not employed in endeavourint
to save their individual property, and with


out the excellent apparatus OF nose, &C


which we have, were not able to content


with the devouring element. They welcom
ed from this quarter as almost provident'al


and they are unbounded in the measure o
: their thanks for the assistance, witbou


which, the best part of the town, with mos
Of the shipping, would have shared the tat


of that valuable portion OF it which was al


ready in flames.


As il was, however, the contiagration va
awful, and the destruction ofpropertv yer
great, as may BE supposed, from iire rag
: ing to the thick Of the town for fVe Ion
: hours, with brisk North West wind blow
, ing. 1t is a wonder, indeed, that the Tar
:, Was t under at All. The hose and forcin
:, machinery, having the river for the sourc
: of supply, furnishing copious and lnexhaus'
y lble supplies Of water. effected what no SUI
ply of water by hand could have done; an'


although the water thrown in streams dt
!, scended in the form of ice and sleet, mani
! ling the firemen in icy garments, we beheN
= but ono of the engines was SO frozen duri'
w the day, as to Sc disabled, SO steadily wei


thev worked.


!, rhc Fire commenced in the Cabinet M

y line number OF Houses destroyed, bcsd

value of the houses and goods destroyed ci

PIGEONS.-By the French law, the lord
had a right to the Young pigeons Of his vas.
sails, except in the March flight. Hartb
supposes that there were, in his time, in
England, $4,000 dove houses, and allowing
500 pair to each house, and four bushels 70
be consumed yearly by each pair. it makes
the loss of corn in a year. thirteen million
bushels. In Persia, the pigeons are trained
to kill the wild unes, of which amusement
they are SO fond, that Christian is not per-
mitted to keep any; and Taverncr, who men
tions this. adds, that some Christians have
become Mahomctans, merely to be entitled
to this privilege,

A nations glory, and her shame,
In silent sadness up.
A nations glory-be the rest
Forgot-she's cannoni-ed his mind.
And it is joy to speak the best
We may of human kind.
I've stood beside the cottage bed
Where the lsard-peasant first drew breath
straw thatched roof above his head,
A straw-wrought couch beneath
And have stood beside the pile,
His monu,nent-that tells to Heaven
The homage of earth's proudest isle
To that Bard peasant given
Bid thy thoughts hover oer that spot,
Boy Minstrel, in thy dreaming hour
And know, however, low his lot,
APoet's pride and power.
The pride that lifted Burns from earth,
The power that gave child OF song
Ascendancy o'errank and birth,
The rich, the brave, the strongi
And if despondcncy weigh down
Thy spirits luttering pinons then,
Despair-thy name is written OH



There have been lofter themes than his,
And longer scrolls, and louder Tyres,
And laysl ait up with Poesy's
Purer and holer fires.
Yet read the names that know not DEATH
Few nober ones than Burns are there,
And few have wona greencr wreath
Than that which binds lis hair.
His is that language of the heart,
In which the answering heart would speak,
Thought, word, that bids the warm tear start,
Or the smile light the cheek,
And his, that music, to whose tone
The common pulse of man keeps time,
In cot or castles mrth or moan,
In cold or sunny cline.
And who hath heard his song, nor knelt
Before its spell with willing knee,
Aud listened, and believed, and felt
The Poets mastery.
o'er the minds sea, in calm and storm,
O'erthe hearts sunshine, and its showers,
O'er PASSIONS moments, bright and warm,
Der Reasons dark, cold hours;
On fields where brave men ode or do,
In halls where ring the banquet's mirth,
Where mourners weep, where lovers WOO.
From throne to cottage hearth
What sweet tears dim the eyes nnshed,
What wild VOWS faltcr on the tongue.
When "Scotts wha hae wi Wallace bled,"
Or "Auld lang Syne" is sung.
Pure hopes, that lift the soul above,


Come with his Cotter's hymn Of praise,
And dreams of youth, and love,


With "Logan's" banks and braes.
And when lie breathed hs master-lay


Of Alloway's witch-haunted wall,
All passions in our frames Of clay


Come thronging at his call,
Imaginaton's world OF air,


And our own world, its gloom and glees
Wit, pathos, poetry, are there,


And deaths sublimity,
And Burns-though brief the race he ran,


Though rough and dark the path he trod,
Lived-tlied--in form and soul Man,


The image of his God


Through care, and pain, and want, and woe,


With wounds that only death could heal,
Tortures-thc poor alone could KNOW,


The proud alone can feei'


lie kept his honesty and truth,


His independent tongue and pen,
And moved, in manhood and YOUTH


Pride of his fellow men.


Strong sense, deep feeling, passions strong,


A hate of tyrant and of knave,
A love Of right, scorn Of wrong,


Of coward and Of slave;


A kind, true heart, spirit high,


That could not fear, that would not bow,
Were written in his manly eye,
And on his manly brow
Praise to the bard!--his words are driven,


Like flower-seeds BY the fair winds sown
Where 'er beneath the sky ofheaYen,


The birds of fame have flown.


Praise TO the man! nation stood


Beside his coffin with wet eyes,
Her brave, her beautiful. her good.


As when loved one dies.

of the proposed Breah'cater at the mouth OF the
Delaware. The expense and difficulty of its con-
structon will be very great, but not perhaps; eS'
coed the proportionate benefits. A list has been
compiled at Philadelphia, in which the remark Is
made. that il contains but a minor exhibit OF the
appalling sutferings Of seamen, and the loss OF
property to individuals and the public, which arc
annually experienced on the coast in the yic'my
of the Delaware Bay for want of proper piacc
of shelter. Between the years 1910 and 1917
no less than one huatired md ainety.one cases Oh
shipwreck, loss and disaster. were occasloned os
vessels being driven out of the bay by storms
and ice. In very many of the cases cited, ah ''lo


individuals on board the vessels were lost' "
well as the property.

But what TO them the sc,ilptors art,
ffis funeral cainmn, wtea'hs, and urns
Wear they not craven on the heart
The name Of itibert Burns i. &. II.

motion was also rejected, as was motion
made by Mr. Williams, to postpone the b,l
to the Sd Of Mirch. The bill was finally
referred back, tn motion Of MIR. Burgess, t'
the Committee If the whole. and made tht
order for tomorrow. The object is to IN
crease the appropriation.


In the Senate, on Wednesday, the bill
for the relief OF Polly Bell WAS discussed
and then laid on the table. The bill for th'
relief Of Ebenezer Oliver and others, Direc
tors Of an association called the 'New. Eng
land nd COMPANY" was considered, an'
supported bv Mr. Robbins and Mr.. Bcrrien
in speeches of some length. The bill max
ing an appropriation for Revolutionary Ot
fcers and other pensioners of the Unite
States, was read twice, and ordered to
third reading.


In the House of Representatives, the mo
tion of Mr. Burses, to take up the bill mak
ing provision for the surviving officers OF ia
revolution was rejected. The House thcr
on motion of Mr., Mallary, went irto Com
mttce of the whole on the state Of the y
MON, and took up the bill for the alteratio
Of the act imposing duties on imports, whe
Mr.. Mallary, in a lucid speech, which ocCt
pied near two bours, explained his ow
views, and those Of the Committee, in rel
ton to our manufactures. On motion OF NJ
Cambreleng, the Committee tAen rose, az
the House adjourned.


In the Senate, ON Thursday, the bill fro
the House of Representatives, granting
township of land for support Of a seminary
learning in the Territory OF Arkansas, WI
reported without amendment. The b
FROM the House of Representative, maki'
appropriations for the Revolutionary and
ther pensioners Of the United States, W
read third time and passed. The Bankru
bill was taken up; the amendments adopt
in the committee of the whole were agrc
70 professionally; and the bill, as anende
was read by sections.


In the House Of Representatives, after t
resolutions had all been offered, "A brief d
cussion took place OH the subject OF the !
10 alter the several acts imposing duties
imports 1t was moved by Mr. Buchan
to discharge the Committee OF the Nh'
on the state of the Union from the furfl
consideration of the bill, with view to f
low up the motion with another, to lay
bill on the table. Mr.. Buchanan discla
ed any thing like hostility to the bill.
expressed his belief that at this adVanc
stage Of the session the bill could not
passed The discussion on the subject Y
cut short, before any vote was taken on
question, by a motion of Mr., Mercer to


eurn. in order that such members as mil
be so disposed. should have the opportur
of giving their assistance to check the


at Alexandria.


Mr. Miner offered resolution to make
appropriation, not exceeding ten thous
dollars, for the relief nf the sufferers by
fire at Alexandria. The humane proposit
was worthy Of its mover.


In the Senate, on Friday, Mr.. Harris
by unanimous consent, produced joint
oiution for appropriating ten thousand I
lars to the INDECENT sufferers BY the late


in Alexandria, to be put in the hands Of
Mayor Of that city for distribution: wi
was read twice, considered and discusse
the Committee of the Whole. and then


ferred to the COMMITTEE on the Distric
Columbia, After spending an hour or


in the consideration Of Executive busin
the Senate adjourned over to Monday.

full articles.headline: DUBLIN POLICE
full articles.article:
Enfraordinlry case, ~ young lady moving in
a respectable station in life, was yesterday com
inittcd to Ncwgatc, from the Head Office, on a
charge Of shop lltltAg.


The circumstances of the case are rather curl
ous and possess in some respects q melancholy
interest. This lady was to have been married on
the very lav that consigned her to disgrace and
imprisonment, to an gnonnous trial and pun
ishmcnt. She was detected on the previous e.
vening, having gone into fashionable shop in
Dame street, accompanied by another young Ia
a. to purchase wedding favours. The young
men in the shop were led to watch her narrowly,
from having few days before missed Grape
shawl and some ribbons after this lady had been
in the shop. On the present occasion she was
observed to secrcta piece Of white ribbon in her
rcticulc, and police officer was sent for, who
took her into custody and brought her to the Of
fee. She gave her name and address, and, on
| being required, the key of her trunk; on search
ing which, the officer found the missing shawl
and ribbons, and fifty pounds in bank notes. The
! young lady WHO was in company with the prison
cr, was excessively shocked at the discovery Of
her friends delinquency; she was of course i'm
mcdiatelv discharged; the other was kept in Gus
tody in the office during the night, and was yes
terlay brought up for further examination Lit
tie more transplrcd than We have already related,





she lad gone into the shop Of a respectable sill
versmith, where she purchased six tea spoons,
but managed At the same time, to secret two or
three triing articles.


The gentleman to whom she was to have been
married, appeared yesterday at the police office,
where he cndeavourcd to console, by his pres.
euce, the object of his affections, verifying the
! words of the poet


81 ask not, care not, if quilts in the heart,
But ! know that love thee whatever thou art. y
, 1t is melancholy consolation to know that the
! lady is one of those who are occasionally fount
addicted to the vice otpilferlng without the temp
tatlon Of necessity Whatever may have led hc1
TO it in the present instance, it is evident from
e the effect her novel situation has produced upol
. her, that shame and anguish rcnd her breast ant
e we understand that those who saw her on t,l,
A previous evening would scarcely have know
!, her when she was brought before the mags
t trates yesterday morning; although the humanit,
of Mr.. Farrell afforded her every accommodation
g that her situation would admit OF through th
night.

The following tribute to Burnss memory,
from the United States ReUeilo and Literary ca
setie, is well worthy Of the high reputation OF
Air.F G. X. who made q pilgrimage to Burns's
shrine in the autumn Of 1922, and now gives us
in the ''thoughts that breathe and words that
burn of true poesy, powerful, discriminating
and touching review Of the "plonShnan MIN
streF' and his ''deathlcss song"
Coleridge at the grave of "Rob Roy and
Campbell when the great kelnble was receiving
his parting honors, show powers equal to inc ac-
complishment of this memorials but beside these
we doubt whether any of the living bards OF
britain (Scott excepted) could have come up to
the choice measure Of Mr. HIS. praise.


~ \, Times.

full articles.headline: MEXICAN AND HAVANA SQUADRovc
full articles.article:
We have been favoured with the tollou;ro,.
tracts of a letter from an officer on board flo =.
S. Frigatc Constitution. The Squadrons ~.
not met, but from the description given of ca "aa
La Borde's men, when they do meet, wc t,;a, MN
it must be upon very unequal terms 'A


Nat Jour,


HAVANA, Dec. 25, 1926


''Last evening the American Ship can,o,
Capt. Watson, arrived in this harbour from w.
diz, and reported he had fallen in with and W..
boarded off Cape Antonio, by Com. por,s.s
squadron, consisting of one Frigote, one H.,
Of Var, tUo Briggs, and 0ne Schooner. Canaan
Wilson went over to the Commodore's shin anil
was requested by him to report on his arrival
that he tcas TO be fouad off Cape Antonio, and
to say he would be happy to see or meet ans ii
the Spanish Squadron that might be ready.A.
Portcr's old friend, Com. La Bordc lost no Tina
in accepting the invitation, by commencing 10
put in state of preparation his dsposable force
consisting of the Loyahy; q frigate ofthe largest
class, and the Arathusa frigate, and Hercules
brig, all crowded with n moiiey cre,r, made up
from the prisons and cells ofthe Moro Castle, &C.
With these vessels he got under weigh, and pa,
sed MS this moment. II is doubtful if he has
not gone to windward first, to fall in with Ii.
Casilda Frgate, and two briggs that went out
some days ago, to cruise tor some Patriot prwa,
teers of Mantanzas., think it not unlikely, as
La Borde is brave, skilful, and prudent officer;
but he can have no support; as his officers and
crew are the most ignorant, motley set Of crca.
lures ever put on board ship. He has to con.
tend Vreport says true. and have no doubt Of
it) with frgate commanded by gallant and
experienced officer of the Yankee school, hav.
ing good officers, and a crew OF English and
.4nericnn sealncn. 1t is said that Porter has one
hundred men more than his complement on
board his o,cn ship, brought out to man pm.
yes: Taking into view the numerical force Of
La Bortle, you would say the Mexican Commo
dorc must be ouer,cheimed; but | am of opinion
if the squadrons come in sight, haJthe Spanisf
force will show no .fght, and that La Borde am
Porter will settle this business. So soon as in
formation arrives of the result of the business
YOU shall hear from me.


The Line-of-bsttle Ship is still here, withoi
masts, &c. Three frgates are here alo ina dis
abled state.

full articles.headline: a ROMAN SAUCE.
full articles.article:
The piedm0NtcSc Gazette relates the toll
lowing discovery recently made in cXcavat-
ing the ruins of Pompeii.


"TURlN, Nov. 23.


1--WE receive from Naples notice Of dis
covcry lately made in Pompei, which will
be highly agreeable to all our readers who
regard the memory of the Romans; this dis
coverp is absolutely new. In the recent cX-
cavatinns of a house near Treiionica, there
were found five glass Jars perfectly closed,
and placed in small wooden box these jars
being conveyed to the Royal Museum, were
carefully cleared of the earth which Coverl,i
the outside, and it was found that two of
them contained a thick and liquid substance
in good preservation, which, Oh accurate ex-
animation, proved to be conserat of olives,
prepared for the table Of some Pompcian
! Gastronome, eighteen centuries ago: they
are still entire which would appear marvel
4 lous If not fabulous, were it not confirmed
! by an authentic report. In another jar there
was a thick buteraceous sauce made OF the
roe of fish. His Majesty the King of the
Two Sicilies, being Immediately informed
of this unparalleled discovery desired to see 1t
and ordered an accurate analysis to be made
Of it.


"Perhaps the sauce here spoken OF is th'
famous Garum, the delight OF the ilastnou
Gourmans, os ancient Rome; it is know
that this suuce was made of the roe of fish
and therefore had much resemblance will
the substance found.


"TURION, Nov IS.
t "The following is the account given Of tn
, examination of the substance found i'll one
the jars at Pompcii. We think it useless t
report the examination of the olives, farthe

served to increase their mutual. r,


lhey were now, of course obliged ~ ,cSSafd
resort to correspondence, but alas bO,. " nave
this to be carried on! for poor Nav muw was
not write. But it was not lone b.fEoro could
received letter from William. in WIZ wb;s, She
declared the Increased ardour Of h;a h'n he
and implored her to marry. She W.. w 'uVs,
compelled to have recourse to a consd.aos nos
female friend to assist her in readinc h.'ial ,h.Ial
ter, and who readily offered to write 'au au e''
swer; but no, Mary could not even - s an
friend impart the main secret, and dec,as,, ne,
the Profered service. yet as true love ;'sd i ss,
dom at loss for the means ofinvention Ma stl'
ry adopted the following concise m.ihos M
Having procured a sheet of writing I,,us nau.
with the end of a burnt stick from oE EF'ps' .S
hearth she formed the little top i, and nc,a. I,c
ed small piece Of sleeps wool, which ho,us' rnus
prised Mary's significant answer, a qvoo"n O',
Her friend wrote the superscription, and !.
letter was sent off, post haste; it was wou ,su
understood, and received with as much rsa, rs'
pleasure, as any bellies iettre could have b.sa ss
Banns were soon after published, and u" tho,'
were married with as little delay as pos,


ble' fO''

than to say, that they are of the species still
cultivated in the kingdom by the names of
Spanish Olives.


"rhs substance is much softer than the
olives; it is of greenish-yellow colour. it
has strong rancid smell, and in the mass
are small globues resembling the roe of fish,
but which strong magnifying glass cannot
well determine. This substance is on the
whole entirely analogous to that found with
the olives; it is composed of the same ele-
ments of oleaginous acid, and of that indie
terminate substance, in some degree analo-
gous to the sweet principle of fixed oils. 1t
should seem that originally it was no other
than olive oil containing some sauce (saisa)
rather than annual, since the distillation of
it has not furnished any compounds of azote.


"NICHOLAS CONELLI.


"Of the Royal Bourborn Museum charg-
ed with the analysis of the substance found
at Pompei


NAPLES, No' 3o."

ity Of the bankrupt act being passed at TINS 80

full articles.headline: .s , his funeral day,
full articles.article:
And still, as his funeral day,
Men stands cold earth-couch around,
With the mu homage that we pay,


To consecFed ground.
And consecrrd ground it is,


The last, II hallowed home of one
Who lives upn all memories,


Though VIII the buried gone.
Such graves his are pigrim-shrnes,


Shrincs to u code or creed contined,-
The DelphiaMaes, the Paiestlnes,


The Mecca Of the mind
sares, with yisdoms garland wrcathed'
Crowned kings, and mitred priests OF power
And wariorsyith their bright swords shea'heo'


The highest Of the hours
And lowlier ,ames, whose humble nome


Is lit bv Frtune's DINNER star,
Are there-,'cr wave and mountain come,
From countries near and lar
Pilgrims wpse wandering feet have prest


The Swt:er's snow, tho Arab S saha,
Or trod the ,iled leaves OF the west


My own green iorest-land.
All ask the cottage of his birth,


Gaze on tie scenes he loved and sung
And gather ceilings not OF earth


His fields and streams among.
They lnger BY the Doon's low trees.


And pastoral Nth, and wooded Ayr,
And round thy sepulchrcs, Dumtues


The Poets tomb is there.
But what TO them the sculptor's art,


ffia funeral caiunn, wteft'hs, and urhs
Wear they not craven on the heart


The name Of llibert Barns r. g. H.

full articles.headline: CURIOUS LOVE LETTER.
full articles.article:
a young woman had lived servant at a
respectable farm house, at the village of
L., lii Northamptonshire, England }
whose sweetheart was an honest rustic Of
the same place, but whom cruel fate had
destined to remove to distant part of the
country, which instead of diminishing, only

A message was received from the presi'
dent bv the House of representatives, COM
munica,ing report from the Secretary OF
State, and the correspondence between VT.
Clay and Chevaier Huggens. on the suo)ect
of the discriminating duties exacted III tue
Netherlands, on importations in American
vessels.

Port Of Tosioa.-Nc are favored by
friend, with til following extract of letter
from his son il Europe, which gives an in
teresting account of the public works at that
port, corresponding with the sketch of our
senior Editor and embracing some subjects
worthy of observation. which time did not
permit him u eXamine.-f.N Y. Statesman.


AarSe2(r&, Oct IA, 1926.


"A visit tc the port of Toulou has engross-
ed much time and attention. After Brest it
is the largest naval depot in France, and is
indeed ast and magnificent establishment.
Nature tas already done much in forming
one of the finest harbors in the Mediterrane-
an, and the ambition of Louis 14th and of
Napoleon has not failed to add every thing
that art could DO TO render those natural adj
vautages as eIfcctual as possible. Almost
every thing necessary in the equipment of
ships OF war, and which is required for the
expenditure of the Arsenal is manufactured
in the establishment itself, such as canvass,
cordage, iron work and the like. These
manufactures and the other work OF the
yard OF course require an immense deal OF
labour, which is performed by about four
hundred galley slaves or convicts, under the
superintendent of large number keep
4 ers. In France, the system OF criminal u-
! risprudence is very mild and rarely involves
the punishment of death; but for great oifenc


es, the criminals are sentenced to hard labor
for life. or for shorter periods, according to
the degree of their criminality. In order to
employ the large number of criminals which
the numerous and dense population ofthis
country naturally affords, they send then to
their different naval arsenals where they are
fed on a healthy vegetable diet, and are kept
constantly well employ ed. Escape is scarce
. ly possible and is almost inevitably followed
by the criminals being brought back to full
fiji an augmented sentence. At Tculon,
there are five three deckers, ten ships of the
lne, and as many frgates, with some small
er vessels. Two ships ct $50 guns built in
1912, bv Napoleon, and called then the
"Austerlitz" and "Marengo," are now SC
completely rotten, as to have been condemn
ed; they were constructed OF green TIMBER
Napoleon thinking to create a navy by the
mere force Of his will. A reply of the ship.
keeper of the no7v "Royal Louis" to my
, question respecting the cruises his worn-o Out


ship had made, will give good idea of the
preponderence of the British Navy, and o


the little efficiency and enterprise of thu
: French. She has made campaigns, Sir, ha


been at eight leagues distance from Toulon
a and even fred several conps-de canon.


:, Oh that we had on our coast such har
? botr and arsenal as Toulon. There bein!


no tide in the Me literrancan, the sea alway


remains at the same level for it Is bas
i. without a river, and is accessible with mos
y winds for any draft. 1t is such a place a


one having most, most needs.

full articles.headline: AWFUL, FIRE AT ALEXANDRIA.
full articles.article:
AWFUL FIRE AT ALEXANDRIA,. A.


A few minutes before nine O'Clock yester-
day morning, an alarming Fire broke out III
the town of Alexandria. 1t was soon per
ceived from this city; and, colG as the
weather was, (thcrmometer at lo') our
townsmen turned out With alacrity and al
most literally flew to the assistance OF 'nei,
neighbours. The Engine from the Capitoi
Hill, with its hose was under way IN rev
minutes after the fire was dlscovered.--A
bout three hundred persons from the Navy
Yard, headed by Captain Booth, were uh-
der way almost as soon, but having lurtner
to 60 did not arrive quite as early on .ie
ground. The Engine from the Post Ol1lcc
Department, with its fine hose got under
way as soon as the fire was ascertalhea 10
be serious, and had just started when an eX-
nress arrived to our Mayor from the Mayor
of Alexandria, soliciting aid, upon which
the Engine of e Second ward, and that
from the First were notified, and were un~
der way. Nor were our Georgetown neigh
bors behind hand: with great SPIRIT they
went down in numbers IN carriages, on
horseback, and on foot, carrying also, 1t IS
believed, their engine. All the Marines on
the station, were also carried down oy Gap
tain IIowle, under the orders OF Col. lien
derson and carrying an engine with them;
and though they did not arrive until the iife
was got under, afforded important service
as guards. The whole number OF persons
who went down from this SIDE OF the river
could not be less than thousand. II we APP
pear to dwell too much upon this pubic spl-
rited conduct of our citizens on TINS occasion,
let it be recollected that the distance to
I 4 4 q. . H.. r. -
I from was seven miles, and that the engines
and men arrived there about the time the


fire WAS most appalling. II any other cause
j for eAultation is thought necessary TO Justi-


fy it. let it be found in the fact, that the fire
was arre stet, and a vast amount oi property


rescued from the Jaws Of destruction, by the


aid thus afforded. The first suocour from the


city arrived about eleven o'clock, and wa


followed by successive supplies. Our friend


at Aiexahdra, exhausted by fatigue ant


anxiety, were not employed in endeavourint
to save their individual property, and with


out the excellent apparatus OF nose, &C


which we have, were not able to content


with the devouring element. They welcom
ed from this quarter as almost provident'al


and they are unbounded in the measure o
: their thanks for the assistance, witbou


which, the best part of the town, with mos
Of the shipping, would have shared the tat


of that valuable portion OF it which was al


ready in flames.


As il was, however, the contiagration va
awful, and the destruction ofpropertv yer
great, as may BE supposed, from iire rag
: ing to the thick Of the town for fVe Ion
: hours, with brisk North West wind blow
, ing. 1t is a wonder, indeed, that the Tar
:, Was t under at All. The hose and forcin
:, machinery, having the river for the sourc
: of supply, furnishing copious and lnexhaus'
y lble supplies Of water. effected what no SUI
ply of water by hand could have done; an'


although the water thrown in streams dt
!, scended in the form of ice and sleet, mani
! ling the firemen in icy garments, we beheN
= but ono of the engines was SO frozen duri'
w the day, as to Sc disabled, SO steadily wei


thev worked.


!, rhc Fire commenced in the Cabinet M
J" ker's Shop of Mr. James Green, on the la
" side of Royal Street, between King al
= Prince streets, aud extended to FairtaX-s s.
! !, thence down Prince street to Unon- stree
y line number OF Houses destroyed, bcsd
Dack buildings, were about forty-and |!


value of the houses and goods destroyed ci
= hardly have fallen short oftwo hundred tho


sand dollars. Some OF the property WAS
= sured, but to what extent we hlvc not hear
~ tho Fire Insurance Company OF Aicxaddri
' : viii, it is supposed, be considerable los
4 by the FIRE The principal sufferers by c
y Of property are, Mr.. Hill, Mr.. Brocchl
$" MIR. Doods, Mr.. Harper, Mr. Johnston, N
u, Rumnry, Mr., Rudd, Mr.. Murphy, Mr.. He
W burn, Messrs. {. & J, p Thompson, NJ
:. Wilson's, the Estate of p. G.. Martellt
=, - iona. G.. May, Mr.. IIorwell, Mr.. Night
W. gale, Isabel Howard, and several oth'


whose names we could not learn.


~ The Office of the Alexandria Gaze
: was in such danger, (though the building I
' o capped, >that the materials were all hast
,:n renewed. aud it will take probably Sol
~, NV days to get the Office so righted as to
W sume publication.


,as


mt DnNIAN cAIrCE

full articles.headline: CHURCH IN BREMEN.
full articles.article:
- A letter from Rev. Mr.. kurtz a Ut, ~ the
an minister now in Europe, published ~ that
New York Christian Advocate .,sn stat in
there is a Lutheran Church at bre.:anabic
Germany, 800 feet long, of a propo.;;'Jh n;Dh ex,


width, with a stecplc seven stores n's''

PIGEONS.-By the French law, the lord
had a right to the Young pigeons Of his vas.
sails, except in the March flight. Hartb
supposes that there were, in his time, in
England, $4,000 dove houses, and allowing
500 pair to each house, and four bushels 70
be consumed yearly by each pair. it makes
the loss of corn in a year. thirteen million
bushels. In Persia, the pigeons are trained
to kill the wild unes, of which amusement
they are SO fond, that Christian is not per-
mitted to keep any; and Taverncr, who men
tions this. adds, that some Christians have
become Mahomctans, merely to be entitled
to this privilege,

full articles.headline: Darien, { Geo. J Jan. 9.
full articles.article:
For five days the paper that had been wet
down for last weeks Gazette remained fro
zen alrng side oft stove. the ink aud oil
were also frozen. The quicksilver in the
below the freezing point during the whole Of
Monday the lst inst.

A nations glory, and her shame,
In silent sadness up.
A nations glory-be the rest
Forgot-she's cannoni-ed his mind.
And it is joy to speak the best
We may of human kind.
I've stood beside the cottage bed
Where the lsard-peasant first drew breath
straw thatched roof above his head,
A straw-wrought couch beneath
And have stood beside the pile,
His monu,nent-that tells to Heaven
The homage of earth's proudest isle
To that Bard peasant given
Bid thy thoughts hover oer that spot,
Boy Minstrel, in thy dreaming hour
And know, however, low his lot,
APoet's pride and power.
The pride that lifted Burns from earth,
The power that gave child OF song
Ascendancy o'errank and birth,
The rich, the brave, the strongi
And if despondcncy weigh down
Thy spirits luttering pinons then,
Despair-thy name is written OH



There have been lofter themes than his,
And longer scrolls, and louder Tyres,
And laysl ait up with Poesy's
Purer and holer fires.
Yet read the names that know not DEATH
Few nober ones than Burns are there,
And few have wona greencr wreath
Than that which binds lis hair.
His is that language of the heart,
In which the answering heart would speak,
Thought, word, that bids the warm tear start,
Or the smile light the cheek,
And his, that music, to whose tone
The common pulse of man keeps time,
In cot or castles mrth or moan,
In cold or sunny cline.
And who hath heard his song, nor knelt
Before its spell with willing knee,
Aud listened, and believed, and felt
The Poets mastery.
o'er the minds sea, in calm and storm,
O'erthe hearts sunshine, and its showers,
O'er PASSIONS moments, bright and warm,
Der Reasons dark, cold hours;
On fields where brave men ode or do,
In halls where ring the banquet's mirth,
Where mourners weep, where lovers WOO.
From throne to cottage hearth
What sweet tears dim the eyes nnshed,
What wild VOWS faltcr on the tongue.
When "Scotts wha hae wi Wallace bled,"
Or "Auld lang Syne" is sung.
Pure hopes, that lift the soul above,


Come with his Cotter's hymn Of praise,
And dreams of youth, and love,


With "Logan's" banks and braes.
And when lie breathed hs master-lay


Of Alloway's witch-haunted wall,
All passions in our frames Of clay


Come thronging at his call,
Imaginaton's world OF air,


And our own world, its gloom and glees
Wit, pathos, poetry, are there,


And deaths sublimity,
And Burns-though brief the race he ran,


Though rough and dark the path he trod,
Lived-tlied--in form and soul Man,


The image of his God


Through care, and pain, and want, and woe,


With wounds that only death could heal,
Tortures-thc poor alone could KNOW,


The proud alone can feei'


lie kept his honesty and truth,


His independent tongue and pen,
And moved, in manhood and YOUTH


Pride of his fellow men.


Strong sense, deep feeling, passions strong,


A hate of tyrant and of knave,
A love Of right, scorn Of wrong,


Of coward and Of slave;


A kind, true heart, spirit high,


That could not fear, that would not bow,
Were written in his manly eye,
And on his manly brow
Praise to the bard!--his words are driven,


Like flower-seeds BY the fair winds sown
Where 'er beneath the sky ofheaYen,


The birds of fame have flown.


Praise TO the man! nation stood


Beside his coffin with wet eyes,
Her brave, her beautiful. her good.


As when loved one dies.
